Hey, Erin. I heard you had a guest actually with you
for today's show.
That's true. Today, I have my special guest Gumby with me.

Who will be telling me
when my CloudFormation steps are ready. Will he rage?

Only as Gumby can. Tim, how about you?
How are you getting the cloud on the phone?

Well, I'm going to have Polly call me
on an actual phone, to tell me how my stacks are doing.

So stay with us on this episode of 'IoT All the Things,
Special Projects Edition.'

Hey, from Brooklyn, everyone. All right, so my name is Erin McGill.
I'm a solutions builder here at AWS.

And for most of my career, I've spent it on the operations side
of the house.

So I've built networks and systems
and data centers, automating the build
and packaging of software

and deploying that. Whether it needs to go on-premises
or in AWS, in the cloud, you know, or both.

And in fact, most of what I do today
in my day job is a combination of IoT
and infrastructure automation.

So that's what brings us
to be getting physical today. That's why I'm wearing... - Why we are wearing all of these...
- It's a lot of work.

Sweat collecting gear. So, since I do
a lot of defining infrastructure as code
and using CloudFormation, I'll be showing you how I've recruited my friend Gumby here,

to let me know
when my CloudFormation stacks are done. What about you, Tim?

So I am Tim Mattison,
I'm a Partner Solutions Architect. I work with IoT Partners
building stuff on AWS.

I have an embedded development experience
in my past as a software engineer, and I just like working on physical projects
that tie into the real world.
So today, we are going to get physical. Yes, we are.

But first, we're going
to get into some topics. Tim, a few days ago,

we were talking about how you have found an alternative
maybe to Bash.

Yeah, I mean,
there's no replacement for Bash. - Everybody loves it.
- There's no replacement for bash. I love it.

But, you know, when you're working with Bash, the Unix philosophy is you take one thing
and you pipe it to another and pipe it to another
and pipe it to another,

but there's no real standard. Everything is just kind of defined
however the developer defined it. And there's a lot of gotchas,

you know, maybe there's a Unicode character
that throws off, whatever you're doing. And you might use tools like sed,
and grep and Awk, or maybe Perl. But nobody uses Perl anymore. All of my favorite tools.

Right, right. We use a lot of them. And there's kind of no way around them
for the most part, but New Shell borrows an idea
that I'm not sure of this,

but I believe that
it's kind of from Microsoft in PowerShell which might be a little controversial.

A little more controversial,
but I've heard good things. Yeah, I mean, there's just a lot
you can do in PowerShell.

There's a guy that I work with, who says you can do anything
in one line of PowerShell. And for the most part, I think it's true.

So, PowerShell instead of sending just text,
it sends these objects, and you can think of them
as like JSON payloads,

between different programs. So you can filter things out really easily. A new shell is a Windows, Linux,
and Mac version of that.

So they've reimplemented the standard tools
to have this nice output. And you can get really slick looking
like text grids to print things out.

You can sort things, filter things,
I think it's really handy, especially, if you were doing a demo
or wanting to visually

like display some data to somebody. It's a lot better than trying
to come up with it on your own. So New Shell is something
that I'm going to be trying out

in the next couple of weeks. And I hear that you have some cool tools
for embedded development

that you want to talk to us about. Well, I myself also have not gotten
to try this out,

but I did come across Rainmaker by Espressif, in a lot of the projects
that I've been talking about

and some of our guests
have been talking about, they've been using Espressif's ESP32-DevKit
microcontroller units. So I'm using that today in my project. And what Rainmaker brings is...

Makes it a lot easier
to kind of onboard your boards to Wi-Fi, you're on your network when you're developing

but also brings an SDK. So today, I coded in C. This makes it a lot easier
to do a lot of the boiler plating
of setting up your codebase and pushing it to your microcontroller.
It also has a phone app on it

so that you can actually interact
with your code running on your microcontroller.

So say you have a light attached to it
or a switch, you can actually, you know, activate that switch
or that light from your phone,
and it will work with your ESP32. So that's super cool.

Another thing that it does is that
it sets up the cloud resources for you. So you don't have to worry about
setting it like,

"Did I set the permissions, right? Did I do the right resources?" That will do it for you, and you can really concentrate on the project
that you're working on.

Yeah, Espressif's got a lot of wizardry that they built around provisioning
and setting things up. So that your mobile app
can push credentials to your device,

it can push the Wi-Fi configuration, they've even built an Alexa integration
that works out of the box. Yeah.

So you don't need to do
that initial plumbing. So I think it offers a lot.
I haven't tried it yet. I know some people
that I work with are using it,

but I really want to get hands-on with it
and check it out. So maybe we'll check that out
in a future episode. Yep.
and how it improved your experience. But, now it's time to get physical.

So today, so what I'm going to show you through, is having something physical
triggered by the cloud.

And this is my friend Gumby. This is actually what we're calling
the awesome contraption,
CloudFormation notifier. So a little bit of trivia from us,

I was going to call this

you know, that's not as common of a phrase. I'm sure you have other phrases
if you live in a different country but that's what we use here.

for you all.

I end up coming to it

I'm going to demo this right now.

I'm going to name it,
New SQS queue with the same name.

This is the one very few times

- So...
- So I'm going to... One of the things
I wanted to bring up was that,

you know,
this is like incredibly useful to me. I'm going to probably use,
maybe not that Gumby part of it, but, you know, some notification system
but there's no detail...

- There's only one Gumby. Yeah, true. There's no default mechanism
to just send you a notification
when a CloudFormation stack launches. I think except you said for SNS will do it. Yeah, you can subscribe to...

You can have it, send a message on an SNS topic
that you've subscribed to. Got it.

So, but you're not using SNS,
can you show us how you did this? I'm not.
And I do have an architecture diagram.

There we go. So... - All right.
- Here we go. We start with CloudFormation, my favorite tool,
then I have created Amazon EventBridge rule, this rule watches the CloudFormation API

and looks for status like, any create status, creating a stack, updating a stack,
executing a change set, anything like that.

Once it recognizes that
those actions are being taken, it then triggers a Lambda function.

So the Lambda function, its whole job is to take the name
of the CloudFormation template
that has been launched or the stack, excuse me, not the template, the stack, and then it creates and configures

another Amazon EventBridge rule
that will run once a minute.

It will run once a minute,
and it will send a compile...

Like a very static payload
to this next Lambda function. That Lambda function will take that payload

which has the CloudFormation name in it,
a CloudFormation stack name in it, and it will describe the stack,
it will pull back the status.

Once the status is any one
of the completed statuses that are possible. So whether it's a success or not,
it will then trigger an IoT topic.

My contraption here
is listening on that predefined topic.

it then gets Gumby going. It does the respective dance. I love it. So the EventBridge rule triggers a Lambda
which then creates another rule.

So it's kind of turtles all the way down. - All the way down.
- Does it... Now after that message is sent to Gumby,

it's probably on wires itself
so that it doesn't keep making Gumby dance, which would be fun but not what you want.
It would be fun, but it is distracting. And sometimes we just got to get to work. So what this Lambda function does is

after it recognizes that
a stack has been completed, it then disables that Amazon EventBridge rule

that had triggered it. So that we aren't just continuously
getting these messages. Because once a CloudFormation stack
is completed,

that's always the status
until you interact with it again, update it, or delete it, or relaunch it, things like that.

Okay, so you're using the ESP32. I actually didn't want to do this project, 'cause I haven't done anything really
with motors before.

I did one project with servos, but somebody else did the hardware for that. So I just needed to write the code
to control them.

So what's the rest of the hardware
that you've got here? Okay, so we have a picture of it.
I'll go through it pretty quickly.

This is the full end-to-end. So you see the cable
going into my Espressif ESP32.

At the bottom that has
that beautiful little amber light on it, and then you see
my TT Motor All-Metal Gearbox.

That's that blue box that has my chopstick with Gumby sitting on top of it,
attached to it.

And then what's in between
is the Adafruit DRV8833 driver motor

that takes the signals from ESP32,
and then drives that motor.

Got it. And that board can do a regular DC motor, but it could do a stepper motor
if you wanted as well, right?

Yeah, it has two inputs and two outputs. So you can either run two motors
like the ones that I have
or you can do a stepper motor. Perfect. All right, so show us the code.

Okay. So I'm just going to show
the significant code.

All of the rest
that's out of the screen is boilerplate, you know, setting up, listening to a topic,

connecting to IoT Core,
and then listening to a topic. So what we have here is once a message
is published to the topic my ESP32 picks it up,
sets stack complete value. Then it pulls out the message payload.

Based on the message, which is the status
that was sent of the CloudFormation stack.
So if it was anyone of the successful statuses, it just sends a...
So you can see: create complete, update complete, or import complete.

So once it does that,
it just sends a high message, high voltage to one of the inputs,
and a low message to the other input.

And that's what gets Gumby to turn. Got it. But, if it is any other status,
then Gumby become sad.

And so what it does is it sets the,
"Oh, no," variable, and then it sets high to one pin,
low to another pin,

for a little bit of time, and then it does the opposite. So it sends the low to the first pin
that had high,

and then high to the one that was low. And so that's why it gets Gumby
to kind of shake his head no

in his disappointed dance. Got it. So just alternates
and makes him move back and forth. - Yeah.
- That's pretty cool.

So like I said, I didn't want to do a motor project,
